TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed SameSiteMode extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Specifies constants that indicate the value for the SameSite attribute of the cookie.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
The behavior of <xref:System.Web.SameSiteMode.None> was modified by updates described in [KB article 4531182](https://support.microsoft.com/help/4531182/kb4531182) and [KB article 4524421](https://support.microsoft.com/help/4524421/kb4524421).
Without these updates, the <xref:System.Web.SameSiteMode.None> value does not emit the `SameSite` cookie header. This conforms to [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-first-party-cookies-07#section-4.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-first-party-cookies-07#section-4.1).
After these updates have been applied, the <xref:System.Web.SameSiteMode.None> value emits the `SameSite=None` cookie header. This new behavior conforms to [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-cookie-incrementalism-00](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-cookie-incrementalism-00). As part of this change, FormsAuth and SessionState cookies will be issued with SameSite = `Lax` instead of the previous default of `None`, though these values can be overridden in web.config.
On systems where these updates have been applied, you can specify the previous behavior by setting the `SameSiteMode` to `(SameSiteMode)(-1)`. You can specify this behavior using the string `Unspecified` in web.config.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Web.SameSiteMode Lax = int32(1)

Docs.summary: The cookie will be sent with "same-site" requests, and with "cross-site" top level navigation.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Web.SameSiteMode None = int32(0)

Docs.summary: The cookie will be sent with all requests (see remarks).

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Web.SameSiteMode Strict = int32(2)

Docs.summary: When the value is Strict the cookie will only be sent along with "same-site" requests.
